0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• evaluate patients for TB (tuberculin skin test) prior to therapy; treatment of latent infection should be started prior to ustekinumab therapy
  • Crohn's disease (Moderate to Severe), Resistant to tumor necrosis factor antagonists: initial, 6 mg/kg IV at week 0; maintenance, 90 mg SUBQ at weeks 8 and 16 was administered in a clinical trial
  • Plaque psoriasis (Moderate to Severe): patient weight 100 kg or less, 45 mg SUBQ initially and 4 weeks later, followed by 45 mg every 12 weeks
  • Plaque psoriasis (Moderate to Severe): patient weight greater than 100 kg, 90 mg SUBQ initially and 4 weeks later, followed by 90 mg every 12 weeks
  • Psoriatic arthritis, Active, alone or in combination with methotrexate: 45 mg SUBQ initially and 4 weeks later, followed by 45 mg SUBQ every 12 weeks
  • Psoriatic arthritis, Active, alone or in combination with methotrexate: coexistent moderate to severe plaque psoriasis and weight greater than 100 kg (220 lbs), 90 mg SUBQ initially and 4 weeks later, followed by 90 mg SUBQ every 12 weeks

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Plaque psoriasis (Moderate to Severe)
  • Psoriatic arthritis, Active, alone or in combination with methotrexate
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Crohn's disease (Moderate to Severe), Resistant to tumor necrosis factor antagonists

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity, clinically significant, to ustekinumab or to any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, including angioedema and possible anaphylaxis, have been reported
  • allergy immunotherapy, concurrent or history, particularly with immunotherapy for anaphylaxis; increased risk for allergic reaction due to decreased protective effect
  • concomitant use with live vaccine not recommended
  • cutaneous squamous cell carcinomas have been reported; risk increases with preexisting risk factors, including age older than 60 years, a medical history of prolonged immunosuppressant therapy, or history of psoralen ultraviolet A (PUVA) therapy; monitoring recommended
  • elderly patients (aged 60 years or older); increased risk of malignancy; monitoring recommended
  • genetically deficient IL-12 and/or IL-23 patients are vulnerable to disseminated infections from mycobacteria, salmonella, and bacillus Calmette-Guerin vaccinations; serious infections and fatal outcomes have been reported; appropriate diagnostic testing recommended as warranted by clinical situation
  • infections, serious (bacterial, fungal, and viral), some requiring hospitalization, have been reported; do not initiate therapy in patients with unresolved or inadequately treated active infections and use caution in patients with latent, chronic, or history of recurrent infections; discontinue therapy if a serious infection develops
  • latex sensitivity; needle cover on the prefilled syringe contains dry natural rubber, a derivative of latex
  • live vaccine administration to household contacts; potential risk for shedding from the household contact and transmission to patient
  • malignancies have been reported; safety has not been evaluated in patients with a known malignancy or a history of malignancy
  • prolonged immunosuppressant therapy, history of; increased risk of malignancy; monitoring recommended
  • psoralen ultraviolet A (PUVA) therapy, prior; increased risk of malignancy; monitoring recommended
  • reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome (RPLS) has been reported; discontinue therapy if RPLS is suspected
  • TB, pretreatment evaluation recommended; do not initiate ustekinumab in patients with active TB and initiate treatment for latent TB prior to administering ustekinumab
  • TB, history of latent or active disease in whom an adequate course of treatment cannot be confirmed; consider antituberculosis therapy prior to initiation of ustekinumab; monitoring recommended during and after treatment
  • vaccination with BCG 1 year prior to, during, or 1 year after discontinuation of therapy is not recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088, or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

1.title: Major
1.mono:
• Adenovirus Vaccine Type 4, Live (theoretical)
  • Adenovirus Vaccine Type 7, Live (theoretical)
  • Bacillus of Calmette and Guerin Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Influenza Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Measles Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Poliovirus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Rotavirus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Smallpox Vaccine (theoretical)
  • Typhoid Vaccine (theoretical)
  • Varicella Virus Vaccine (theoretical)
  • Yellow Fever Vaccine (theoretical)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Immunologic:Infectious disease (27% to 72.3%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (5%)
  • Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (7% to 8%), Upper respiratory infection (4% to 5%)
  • Other:Fatigue (3%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Skin cancer, Non-melanoma (1.5%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction, Infectious disease, Serious infections (0.3% to 2.8%)
  • Neurologic:Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome
  • Other:Angioedema, Cancer (1.7%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ustekinumab is a human IgG1-kappa monoclonal antibody that binds to the p40 subunits of the interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23 cytokines which are involved in inflammatory and immune responses.

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Vd, IV: 56.1 to 82.1 mL/kg
  • Vd, subQ: 161 to 179 mL/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • for subQ injection only
  • single-use vial: inject using a 27-gauge, 0.5-inch needle and rotate injection sites
  • prefilled syringe: inject full contents of syringe; maintain pressure on plunger head and remove from skin; slowly allow empty syringe to move up to cover needle with needle guard
  • avoid injections into tender, bruised, erythematous, or indurated skin

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• psoriasis: improvement in psoriatic lesions is indicative of efficacy
  • psoriatic arthritis: normalization of serum C-reactive protein levels, improvement in the number of swollen or tender joints, or reduction in joint pain is indicative of efficacy
  • appearance of non-melanoma skin cancer; especially patients greater than 60 years of age, and patients with a history of prolonged immunosuppressant therapy or psoralen UV-A (PUVA) therapy
  • TB test; prior to initiating therapy
  • TB, active; signs or symptoms during and after therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause angioedema (ie, swelling of the face, lips, tongue, throat). Advise patient to seek immediate medical attention if one or more of these symptoms occur.
  • Advise patient that live vaccines are not to be taken during therapy due to drug-induced immunosuppression.
  • Advise patient to take caution with household members receiving live vaccines as viral shedding may result.
  • Patients should not receive the Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG) vaccine the one year before taking ustekinumab, during ustekinumab therapy, or one year after ustekinumab treatment is stopped.
  • Instruct patient to notify doctor immediately with symptoms of an infection.
  • Drug may cause nasopharyngitis, upper respiratory tract infection, headache, and fatigue.
  • Advise patient to notify doctor if symptoms of reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome (ie, headache, seizures, confusion, vision problems) occur.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of hypersensitivity (eg, pruritus, erythema, flushing, urticaria, or other rash).
  • If appropriate, a patient or caregiver may administer the drug. Teach patient or caregiver proper injection technique and disposal. Supervise and evaluate first injection.
  • Needle cover on the single-use prefilled syringe contains latex. Patients sensitive to latex should not handle needle covers due to risk of allergic reaction.
